reviews.title: Classic Lighter
reviews.body:
I really dont like the disposable lighters for many reasons. I just cant stand throwing them away a product that is really still good to use if you could refill it. I figure that one $10 purchase to get a zippo is worth it. I have really enjoyed this lighter from the moment it arrived.
It really lights in the wind so we use it to start fires in our outside fireplace very often. We have replaced the wick a few times and also the flints but they are really easy to manage. Make sure you just buy some flints, wicks and fluid so you have them when needed. We are not smokers but we use the lighter often to light candles and fires. Its a good purchase.
How I rate --
5 Stars: Works exactly as advertised, is a good value at the price point purchased, would buy again or recommend to a friend.
4 Stars: Works mostly as advertised, fit/finish are what you'd expect when purchasing this type of product, might have a minor flaw.
3 Stars: Generally works but it may not be a good value at the price point or might like to see changes / improvements.
2 Stars: Barely works but can be made useful if you try.
1 Star: Useless, does not perform its intended function whatsoever and is generally a waste of money, sending it back.
Overall: I am giving this a five star rating based on my criteria above. The lighter is worth every penny in my opinion. It works well and should last a lifetime. If you have any questions or comments, please feel free to ask in the comments. I will try to respond. If you found my review helpful or lacking also let me know I like to continuously improve. I hope this helps you with your decision making process.

reviews.title: High Quality Product
reviews.body:
Its a classic design that draws respect for its faultless looks and function. Fits my hand perfectly, nothing cumbersome about it, perfect flame every time. The 1.5x thick chrome finish makes it distracting in looks, a really beautiful lighter. Amazing how little this lighter design has changed since 1932 when it was invented.
I quit smoking in 1976, but I've always missed having a Zippo. I'll keep this around and in my car for when I need a reliable flame.

author.name: ByAdam B

reviews.title: Good but...
reviews.body:
This lighter is the time-tested fluid lighter that has been used for the last half century.
It works great, is durable and windproof (except in a full gale). As soon as I filled it with lighter fluid I was set.
I also placed a couple of extra flints inside the lighter (under the bottom felt pad) for replacement of the flint.
I prefer this over the butane lighters because lighter fluid stores easily, refills are quick and easy and the lighter works for quite a time before needing another fill.

author.name: ByRYAN MACEWEN PRUYN

reviews.title: What can I say bad about it Its a nice lighter for cheap
reviews.body:
This lighter is the time-tested fluid lighter that has been used for the last half century.
It works great, is durable and windproof (except in a full gale). As soon as I filled it with lighter fluid I was set.
I also placed a couple of extra flints inside the lighter (under the bottom felt pad) for replacement of the flint.
I prefer this over the butane lighters because lighter fluid stores easily, refills are quick and easy and the lighter works for quite a time before needing another fill.

author.name: ByErnesto Rivera

reviews.title: It's not broken -- don't fix it.
reviews.body:
Seller gave excellent service, i.e. the product arrived quickly and in brand new condition as promised.

This is a great lighter, brand new yet you own a piece of history in your hands. It was/is in perfect shape, and lit up right out of the box, after putting in fuel, as they come delivered empty. I don't smoke and have no plans to start, but as I posted in a previous review, a "man" should carry a lighter. This is a bit larger than my other zippo, a slimline version, but otherwise exactly the same.

These lighters take a bit more work than average. You might think of it as driving a stick shift verse a manual. On the flip side they are much cooler, and much more reliable. The price, even with shipping is way below retail.

I would highly recommend this to anyone who feels the need to carry a lighter, smoker or not. They are fun to play with at the very least, and single men, ladies really do love it. Don't be a loser with a 99 cent bic! This lighter is great for women too, you're liberated and don't really need a man to light that cigarette after all, but please, if a nice guy like me offers, indulge us.

I will say that after thoroughly washing the lighter, and my hands, I am not too concerned with the inability to wash the "fingerprints "off of the lighter, being that it is sterling silver and has started to tarnish, because I'm planning on customizing this lighter completely and will send pictures when complete.

reviews.body:
Not too bad. I am glad everyone seems happy with their purchase. As for the extra thickness, I find it hard to discern. Admittedly, I gave up smoking many years ago although at that time I did use Zippos. I do not recall them being substantially thinner and weaker than this one and therefore must conclude that Zippo has reduced its standard frame dimension while I was away.

I bought this for camping and due to its wind proof nature, I am confident in it. (Of course redundancy never hurts either, I have a pack of strike anywhere's as well as a flint and fire starter in my bag). Overall, not a bad purchase, but when I got mine I was surprised it did not feel beefier.

reviews.title: Fluid evaporates rapidly, so it never lights when I want it too.
reviews.body: I must confess, I have not used a Zippo lighter since I was in my 20's which was quite a time ago. But I do not remember having to refill the fluid once a week or replace the flint every two weeks as is the case with this lighter. Having gotten use to butane lighters, I have become accustomed to getting months of service from a fuel refill and virtually never having to replace the flint (if the lighter was not using electronic ignition). I have put this lighter aside in my junk drawer and have purchased a full size Zippo lighter and a butane insert. That is the best of both worlds and I really like the combination.

For people like me that are clumsy and always dropping things, this lighter is perfect because I didn't mind adding more scratches to the lighter every time I dropped it. In fact, it added character. Have to mess with refilling fuel and changing flints

Bottom line: I will buy again if I ever lose the one I have.

author.name: ByJake Hancher

reviews.title: Nice
reviews.body: Bought this for a experimental/survival tool. I felt the thicker body and lack of paint would help it hold up to use of non standard fluids while the high polish chrome finish would let it double as a reflective device. The body's inner dimensions are slightly longer than that of the insert. this creates an air gap that does not exist in my standard body zippo. This caused my armor zippo to drain of fluid in less than three days versus my other one. However I came across a remedy for fluid drainage altogether: I created a seal out of bicycle inner tube that has allowed this lighter to hold fluid(denatured alcohol this time) for over 2 weeks now. This is an idea that people looking for the Zippo as a prepping item can look to. I used one strip each at the base and lid(each meeting flush with the seam) and a third meeting over them.

reviews.title: Overall its not the best zippo you will be but it definitely serves the ...
reviews.body:
If you keep a zippo around in case of a survival situation, it will likely be out of fluid when you need it.
You can take the cotton out of it, and fill the cavity with vaseline soaked cotton balls. If you need to start a fire, pull out a ball, spread out the fibers, and get a spark from the zippo. You can also carry extra flints in the cavity with the cotton balls. Look it up on youtube.

reviews.title: Love It!
reviews.body:
I am again, 100% satisfied with this purchase. I was critical of someone else on another Zippo model because he was complaining that the fluid evaporated out after 3 days. I would expect that in a device like this. A zippo to me, is an emergency lighter. Just keep zippo fluid around. It is easier in my opinion to tell you if you have a full bottle of zippo fluid, than a full canister of butane. Plus, I would think it would be easier to obtain. I am not sure if zippos can use other fuels like naptha in an emergency, but I will be checking into it.

I ramble, but I wanted to say, I got mine over a week ago, filled it, and it still has fluid, so maybe mine seals better.

This device is very solidly built to tight clearances. It has a very high quality feel to the entire thing. The hinge and seal are flawless.

A big plus is, this is one of the few remaining American owned companies. They manufacture these in the US.

You could get a cheap Chinese knock off, but it wouldn't be near as good, and you would be helping the Chinese economy, not your fellow citizens and yourself in the US keep jobs, and stimulate the economy.

I know the later doesn't mean much to most people, but it really should.

Thank you for your time, and I hope this is helpful to you.

Mark :)

reviews.title: good, i like
reviews.body:
If you are looking for a Zippo, chances are you want to do more than light a cigarette; you're probably getting this lighter to do tricks. If so, this is a good lighter to go with, it's a functional basic Zippo.

However, if you think you're going to be playing around with this thing for a while, you might seriously want to consider getting a slightly better looking one (perhaps black, or with a zippo logo) for a couple of extra bucks. I got this lighter last week, and am already in love with it and trick with it all the time; I already wish I had a fancier one to show off...

Also, remember this is a refillable ZIPPO lighter from which fuel dries over time if not used, HENCE IT COMES WITH NO FUEL FILLED(duh!). So do yourself a favor, and buy Zippo lighter fluid right now with the lighter and don't curse yourself later about having to pay shipping twice.
The fuel you'll need: 4oz Lighter Fluid, Single Can (ZI3341)

reviews.title: Love It!
reviews.body:
The Zippo was born in 1932, and the popularity of this lighter became legendary during WWII among all armed services members. Although Zippo had no contract with the Government to manufacture, it was the demand from the service men that this lighter be available for sale at the military stores (PXs) on bases and instillations.

Its guaranteed for life even if you arent the original owner. Find a mashed or broken one and send it to Zippo for replacement/repairno questions asked.

The sound and feel of opening the top to ignite it is distinctive as well as the sound and feel of closing of the top to extinguish it. The care and maintenance of the Zippo is a bit more than for a disposable butane lighter, but the Zippo will light outdoors in a strong wind, usually on the first try. The disposable butane lighter wont.

I was missing this piece of Americana. Now I have it back.

reviews.title: Zippo~
reviews.body:
I wasn't aware that the fluid would evaporate even without use. 1 full refill will evaporate in 2 weeks of carrying in your front jeans pocket. I don't smoke but bought this lighter because it's an American icon and American made. I wanted to have a lighter for preparedness situations. Needless to say, a zippo is NOT for people wanting to have a lighter for survival unless they know when the exact day will happen that they will need the lighter for an emergency, highly unlikely. I will purchase a small bic lighter as my every day carry lighter for emergencies.
I'm very disappointed that there was no up front information from anyone one, including the manufacturer about the fluid running out even if you never light the flame. Why carry it if it loses its importance in two weeks. A lighter should light when needed. I've had to fill it every few weeks just to ensure I'll have a flame when necessary.

reviews.title: zippo
reviews.body:
I was delighted when I opened the package and saw this lighter. I wanted a Zippo that could be carried around in my pocket with loose change, a money clip, and other items which could mar the surface of a lighter. The random scratch pattern on the surface is actually quite attractive. Any minor "new" scratches will be completely invisible on this unit. The rest of the Zippos in my collection are "collectables," and I want to keep them pristine, since the ones with logos and art work ARE in fact, works of art. Mechanically, all Zippos are pretty much identical. They light easily, and they are of such simple design, that they function flawlessly. I've been collecting flint & fluid types of lighters since I was a kid in the 1950's, and I have yet to have owned one that I couldn't get to light. They are quite simply, too simple not to work! If you have a flint loaded, and flick the thumbwheel and it produces a spark, and you have a half inch of lighter fluid soaked wick, it WILL light. It doesn't have any choice! It would even light with non-approved fuels, like naphtha based lantern fluid, or even gasoline (I learned this when I was a dumb kid). I have a warning though: DON'T USE UNAPPROVED FUEL!!!!! Gasoline has dyes and other additives which will quickly foul your lighter, and it produces a horrible smell. Lantern fuel (such as Coleman) is similar to lighter fluid (naphtha is the key ingredient in gasoline, lantern fluid, and lighter fluid), except it burns hotter, and will evaporate quicker. DON'T USE IT. To do so would be dangerous. Use approved fuel only, such as Zippo, or Ronsonol (which is now made by Zippo). Why do I say that you MUST use an approved fuel? Because cigarette lighter fuel contains retardants which produce a more controlled burn rate, and also retards evaporation so that you don't have to refill the lighter as often. There is also the safety factor here to consider, in having a less volatile fuel.

OK, so where do you get flints and lighter fluid? Before the highly reliable, long-lasting, disposable butane lighters were invented, lighter fuel was available virtually everywhere: Mom&Pop stores, hardware stores, grocery stores, drug stores. In fact, it was hard to find a store where it WASN'T available. DON'T buy flints and fluid online. It is way too expensive, and they are not that hard to find in stores. I found the Zippo 12 oz. cans of fluid at my local grocery store (a well known national chain, which I don't want to plug) and it was priced at $3.50. The best place however, to buy flints and fluid is at the nation's largest retailer (the one founded by the late Sam Walton). It is usually located at one of the check stands. They sell Ronson flints for 40 cents (5 pack), and Ronsonol fuel (8 oz. can) for $1.65 (I'm plugging Ronson/Ronsonol because it's made by Zippo). Also, you can obviously find these products at specialty stores which sell pipe tobacco, cigars, etc. These are usually located in shopping malls and strip malls. You might pay a bit more at the specialty stores, but still, it would be cheaper than having to pay shipping and handling charges for online purchases.

User problems:

I still can't get over the number of people who think that this type of lighter should come filled with fuel. They aren't allowed to ship them that way. These lighters are not sealed units and are subject to evaporation. A tightly sealed shipping carton would fill up with volatile fumes. Such a box might even technically be considered a BOMB!

Can't get it to light?

(1) Sometimes after filling the lighter, raw fuel gets onto the flint, or the wick is oversaturated (too wet). Leave the lighter upright with the top open, and evaporation will take care of this problem. In a few minutes, try again.

(2) Bad Technique? If you are new to this type of lighter, you may be having trouble with the thumbwheel. Practice your technique. Flints are cheap! Remember when you were a kid, and somebody taught you how to snap your fingers, to make a very loud pop? It is the same sort of technique for operating the thumbwheel. A wimpy turn of the wheel will produce little if any spark. A hard, quick snapping of the wheel will produce a massive spark, and increase your chance of success.

Some final thoughts & suggestions:

These flint and naphtha based fuel lighters are relics of the past, and are best thought of as nostalgia, or collectable art pieces. If you are going camping or hunting, ALWAYS carry spare matches, or a butane lighter with you as a back-up. As several people have mentioned, these lighters lose fuel fairly rapidly due to evaporation. Always fill them on the day of your outing, and bring spare fluid and flints with you (Zippo makes a cute little key-chain canister which holds one lighter full of fuel, and an extra flint, available from Amazon). Another good reason that you MUST keep your lighter well fueled, is that the wick will burn up when it goes dry, and you will have to replace it.

I must have got a used one because it has hundreds of little scratches all over it. I don't understand.
Update: I have recently been informed by representatives of the Zippo corporation that the scratches on my lighter were placed there on purpose. They also offered to send me a custom edition polished brass zippo with a years supply of lighter fluid, wicks and flints if I change my review from three stars to five. I am happy to oblige!

reviews.body: The classic Zippo is an outdoorsman's essential worthy of it's iconic stature in the realm of consumer products.  For the hunter, camper, hiker, and general enthusiast of things outdoors, your backpack or pocket will feel lonesome with the Zippo at arms length.  Have one; or two.  It's an essential.

reviews.title: It's all scratched up
reviews.body:
This is the first Zippo Lighter i've bought.
It works great from what i can review about it. The top has only bent a little bit once do to my mistake and i bent it right back so it clicks back on perfectly. When i fill it with gasoline i can leave it in a drawer for a week and it still lights (a second 3 dollar zippo i purchased wont light unless refilled right beforehand.) The wick doesn't burn away like paper even after long time use. It makes a fantastic sound, feels great in my hand, looks clean and polished, and isn't that expensive from other prices in the US i've seen. Works great.

author.name: ByGuillermo

reviews.title: Zippo lighter the best
reviews.body:
As a kid the Zippo was a legend, "Lights in the rain. You can always count on it." Well, after what - 5 months of mucking about with this pair, I've gotten one to (after filling, refilling, setting upside down over night. reaching in deep to get fluid as close to the wick as possible, etc., to light 7 times in one session. Then it failed to light but once again over four of days of flicking it several times a day. (Checking fluids, shaking, storing upside down.) Voila, lit - once. Never again. The other lighter has never lit up. Same treatment, testing filling, repeated attempts over several weeks. Nope. Nada. The light's gone out. Believe me I've checked and trimmed wicks raised and lowered flame level - even went so far as to use "Zippo" lighter fluid - though of course they're all the same.

Maybe you'll get lucky. Maybe I got a bad one - but 2 at the same time? Zippo used to claim "We fix it no matter what." Well I can't find them. If I hadn't fiddled with them for so long, I'd have sent them back, though how I'd have gotten a canister full of flammable liguid thru the mail remains a mystery. So spin the wheel - maybe you'll win the lottery. I'm reduced to cheapo, chinao, plastic junk. Oh, how the mighty have fallen.

reviews.title: Three Stars
reviews.body:
I was always fascinated with Zippos when I was young but I never had a reason to have one. I don't smoke but a lighter is a useful thing to have around the house so I figured I would go ahead and get a Zippo instead of buying more disposable lighters. I like the lighter but I found out pretty quickly that the fluid will evaporate before you get a chance to use it if you don't use it on a regular basis.

I just refilled mine about a week ago and when I went to use it tonight, the flame was already small and flickering a bit, like when the lighter needs to be refilled. I got the lighter at the very end of January and have already filled it at least three times. I don't believe there's anything wrong with my particular lighter - the lid isn't bent and closes tightly. To be fair, I live in a dry climate so maybe that accelerates it? Either way, in my experience, you're might be better off with a plain old butane lighter if you don't use lighters daily.

reviews.title: excellent ; but scratches easily
reviews.body:
It's a zippo. It looks cool, and is good for lighting things. I bought this more to do tricks to impress people though.

I wouldn't say it's exactly windproof. I would say it's more "wind-resistant." For what I was doing with it though, that wasn't really an issue.

Zippos have a tendency to have weak hinges, that eventually break. This is true. Additionally, if you drop this thing while doing a trick, the top might be a little crooked. I didn't do it personally but I've seen it on other peoples' lighters ; D

Another thing is, the lighter fluid on these things evaporates pretty quickly. I'm in Boston, so the air isn't exactly dry like, say, Denver, Colorado (very dry there). So, if you're going to get one of these, you have to use it often to make it worthwhile.

If you use it occasionally, and mostly put it in a drawer, it's not worth it. You'll end up wasting money on lighter fluid that's going to evaporate.

NOTE: This lighter's made of metal. If you light it for too long, it gets hot. This is somewhat annoying when you put it back in your pocket.

Using this to light candles is a dumb idea. It's made for cigarettes. I don't personally smoke, but my friend says he can taste the lighter fluid when I give him a light, so in that respect, it's kind of a fail.

It's fun to do tricks with these. For other uses, looks cool, but maybe not so practical?

author.name: Byjohn g

reviews.title: ehhh
reviews.body:
I was super excited when I ordered the "Zippo Street Chrome " lighter for my son, because the item ad stated that it used "Butane" fuel, and I love the cleaner burn of it over the traditional "Lighter Fluid". Well, the box arrived in less than 2 days, which was great, but when I opened the lighter & discovered that it in fact used lighter fluid my excitement diminished:( I had specifically searched for "Butane Lighters" and this lighter showed up & clearly states fuel type as butane, so beware of these errors in product description.

Other than my disappointment with the fuel issue, overall the lighter is a great quality, works great & most importantly, my son loves it!!!!!

reviews.title: Good while it lasted..
reviews.body:
I am not a smoker. I do however work in a restaurant where I constantly need a lighter to light candles. I have bought countless disposable lighters over the years and saw a Zippo here for only $9 and some change, so I decided to go for it.

These are nicely constructed of steel with a sturdy hinge. The best part is they are made in America. The lighter is very different from the Bic at the corner store you may be used to. It uses a compartment filled with cotton batting that you soak with lighter fluid. At first I thought something was wrong. The area where the lighter fluid goes is not really air tight nor does it have a secure bottom. In fact there is only a piece of felt that keeps excess fluid from leaking out of the bottom of the lighter. But I digress. The lighter lights very easily as the flint produces a robust spark. However, when you turn the lighter on its side to light a candle the flame does not protrude from the "chimney." It makes lighting candles rather difficult, to the point where I immediately went back to my old disposable.

This is a great lighter for a smoker. It does withstand a fair amount of wind without going out as well. For everyone else I recommend looking elsewhere...maybe the Zippo butane lighter.

reviews.title: good seller
reviews.body:
Not sure if this is a genuine zippo. If it is not genuine then it is a very good fake. The insert is genuine but they could have bought the cheapest zippos available to get the inserts. The case is well built with the year, zippo stamp, the word "sterling", an armor symbol, and "MADE IN U.S.A.". However, the lid and base of the case don't fit correctly. When the lighter is laid on a flat surface, one side has a gap about the width of a fingernail. That doesnt sound like much but when the lighter is closed and the gap is closed, you can see that the top is skewed to one side. That is not a huge deal but none of my other zippos have this issue. I am almost positive that the case is sterling silver because it is not magnetic, the weight seems correct, and it will tarnish in a new York minute.

I ordered my lighter from D3als4you (seller on Amazon). The lighter is not the brushed finish you may expect. It looked like it was ever so slightly brushed but the brush marks dissapeared in a day. No joke. It was like someone brushed it by hand with a rag. It really is a great lighter but if it is not a genuine zippo it is only worth about $40. That's the cost of this type of lighter plus silver weight. The only way to tell for sure if it is genuine is to send to zippo for repair or compare against a known genuine zippo from the same year 2014. I may just do that and then update this post. Good luck and I hope this was helpful.

It does not come with fluid you will have to buy that separately (I've ordered some fluid from amazon, review coming shortly) but you cant mark it down for not coming with fluid because it says it doesn't. its a good basic zippo that i recommend to anyone who wants a zippo but doesn't quite want to pay a small fortune for the high end zippos on the market, i recommend this to anyone new to zippos, overall really great product.

Now for the downsides, sometimes when in my pocket whilst on the move the insert comes out slightly this is terribly annoying as i keep having to pop it back in, also i noticed on the inside of the case there are yellow stains, not sure if thats with all zippo lighters or not.

comes in a really nice black box to store and display the lighter, comes with a small booklet with info on zippos

author.name: ByAllen

reviews.title: good but not perfect
reviews.body:
my humble opinion:
i was gonna wait a few days and put up this review on the first of the month and complain that it didn't have fluid and that there was a sticker on it that left a bunch of glue that only a wizard that was trained in dark magic could remove..oh! and the scratches...
BUT, i figured i would have confused the slower folks. (get it?-april 1st?)
*sigh*
moving on>
this is the deal of the century.
an American made lighter with a lifetime guarantee shipped for free in 2 days (i have prime so you peasants... should step aside.) for under 10 bucks???
i must have stepped off the bus in Crazytown (nice place).
i would have bought 2 but why? if i don't lose it 1 will last a lifetime.
-i love the build. it's an engineers dream. super simple and super functional.
-i love the finish (street chrome). why? because standard chrome is too slippery and the girlies need to think i have change in my pocket (i don't--i used it to buy a zippo)
-i love the smell. c'mon guys! admit it! zippo fumes and wd-40..the best smells ever!
ain't life great? i submit that it is.
my tips for a better zippo experience (take my advice at you own risk but this is what i do)
-i keep it full but never overfull.i use only zippo or ronson fluids and flints.
-i keep an extra flint under the felt and i only finger-tighten the flint screw
-i dab an extremely small amount of superglue on the ends of the hinge pin to keep the pin from sliding out. the old sliding pin syndrome has shelved many a great zippo. it only takes a teeny little drop.too much and you'll get glue in the pin and mess up your rig, so don't do this unless you're slick.
thats what i do. it's up to you if you want to.
enjoy your lighter.
i hope i helped.

author.name: ByP. Antal

reviews.title: To small., not even standard lighter size.
reviews.body:
Zippos are classic lighters and a fashion accessory, and the appearance and sound of these lives up to that. It's a beautiful piece and that "flick" sound is just so satisfying.

That said, as soon as you get it in your hands, the disappointment starts. The lid doesn't align with the body very well. I knew before buying that the fuel evaporates, but I was surprised that is only takes 5-7 days for it to evaporate from full to empty *without use*. I thought it would take at least two weeks. The evaporation rate might be a problem with my expectations, but I can't help but think that if the lid fit more snugly, it would evaporate more slowly.

When you actually try to light the lighter, it's even more disappointing. I don't think there has been a time I've successfully lit it on my first try. Typically it takes 3-5 tries to get it lit. That's really crippling to this being a good fashion accessory. When you see the guy with his leather coat lighting a cigarette in a noir film, he doesn't spend thirty seconds fiddling with his lighter. Failing to light your lighter does *not* make you look badass. 79 cent BIC lighters light on the first try, why can't a Zippo?

You know those movies where the guy lights a Zippo and then tosses it into a gasoline covered car or building or whatever he wants to burn? I used to think that was a waste of a perfectly good zippo. Now I realize he just got it to light on the first try for the first time ever, and has decided to quit while he's ahead.

reviews.body:
just used this today - went to the cemetery to visit my parents and being of chinese descent we burn alot of "offerings"... that is we give our deceased loved ones money and material things for the afterlife by burning paper representations of it anyhoo...

anyway i had a very mini butane torch and it was a hassle refueling it plus it was temperamental but it would go out on a windy day - also tried kitchen butane lighters and regular bic-like butane lighters but it would go out with the slightest breeze.

so i bought a zippo 'windproof' lighter for these occasions - and this did the job. it wasn't hurricane windy but it was windy enough that i would have had trouble with the aforementioned various butane equipment. broke out my new zippo fueled up the evening before and it does as advertised - lit my incense - it stayed light even when the wind blew in various directions - it was on for a good 3-4 min without any trouble. lit the candles as well.

i chose this particular 'design' brushed chrome because nothing is as elegant as an understated zippo and it's well made. and it's made in the USA.

the missus approves too -- so happy wife happy life.

i don't smoke ... but when i burn offerings i use a zippo.

reviews.title: Love It!
reviews.body:
LEGEND* (products that are absolutely fantastic or have been incorporated to my daily life will be marked with a "LEGEND" symbol)

**UPDATE**- Went skiing, lit a cigarette with minimal effort while on a ski lift, with wind and SNOW BLOWERS blowing over it. Amazing product!

Chances are, you already know about this nifty little lighter!

They've been around for quite a while and everyone who has them, seems to have had them for a while. Some that I've seen are much older than a lot of us! The thing with these are, yes they light amazingly in almost any weather (they even pass the fan test! youtube "Zippo fan test") but more importantly, they hold stories. The things some of these lighters have been through far outweigh anything you and I have ever seen. They are built for life. Which is why they have a Lifetime Warranty.

Their warranty is phenomenal. I've had nothing but good experiences with them. They will fix ANY Zippo lighter, even if it was your fault.

Again, these lighters are great, if you are willing to upkeep it. It does use Zippo (save $ by buying Ronsonol) Naphtha fluid which is NOT INCLUDED. It is illegal to ship these types of lighters with fluid in it. It will eventually need more flint, and extra wick. Both fairly cheap and easily available with Amazon Prime. Unfortunately, it holds the fluid in a NON AIRTIGHT chamber of a cotton like material called "Rayon". In short, cotton comes from the plant and is harvested relatively quick, while rayon comes from the tree (bark) and takes YEARS to harvest. Although cotton is much stronger than rayon, rayon is far more absorbent than cotton and wicks exceptionally better. Unfortunately since the Zippo is not airtight, it "leaks" fuel. If not in use, the fuel will eventually evaporate, leaving you with a fireless lighter.*

*PRO TIP: You can remedy the fuel leak issue, by taking a tire tube (or any tight, round, stretchy rubber material), stretching it out and inserting the Zippo around the crease of where the lighter opens. You can just roll the rubber down when you need to light, and you will refuel less frequently!

^also, they have a butane insert made for Zippo lighters called "thunderbird butane insert" which will basically make your Zippo into a refillable BIC style lighter. They are extremely useful and well worth the $

PRO TIP: You can keep extra flints (I'd recommend 2-3) right under the cotton "flap" to the fluid filling chamber. You can simply refill fluid regularly because the extra flints doesn't affect the lighters performance in any way. This helps tremendously in a survival situation, because with a spark, you can have a fire.

-PRO TIP- WHEN YOU FIRST RECEIVE YOUR ZIPPO-: unscrew the screw and take out the flint spring. Ensure the extra bit of wick "zigzags" around the Rayon balls.
ZigZagging:
-Take the Rayon balls out of the middle of the filling chamber (The one piece of rayon wedged to the side doesn't matter)
-Extend the extra wick fully, then insert a little wick, then rayon, then cross over with wick, then rayon, repeat.
-Kind of like an "S" shape. This will help the wick transfer fuel better thus helping the lighter light more efficiently.

If you think this review was helpful in any way, there is a button to let me know! So I keep doing it! Thank you! :)

reviews.title: Good zippo.. No fluid
reviews.body:
Classic ZIPPO quality. Proudly made in USA. This is the "Slim" size, about 70% the size of a Standard size. Same height, but about 30% narrower. A pattern virtually unchanged since the 1930s, backed by a lifetime warranty that they actually honor, no questions asked.

Solid 'click'. Feels good in the hand. All ZIPPOs are mechanically identical, only the case finish differs.

ZIPPO offers 4 'Chrome' finishes--High Polished Chrome(a mirror finish), this Brushed Chrome, a sandblasted flat-matte 'Satin Chrome' and a 'Street Chrome" which is the High Polished Chrome after being lightly pre-scratched as if in a tumbler.

For new ZIPPO buyers: All lighters in the USA are by law shipped 'dry' (without fuel), so you'll want to buy ZIPPO brand or Ronsonol brand lighter fluid from any drugstore or WalMart near you. About $5 for 12 oz, and that will last you a LONG time. Filling takes about 10 seconds. Instructions come with your ZIPPO and there are tons of useful how-to's on youTube, the ZIPPO website and on the various online Lighter Forums.

Lighter fluid (naptha, and not the same as "charcoal lighter fluid") gradually evaporates over a couple of weeks or so out of any lighter (even if not used) and will need refilling.
New ZIPPO owners are sometimes surprised to learn that they can't just drop this in a drawer for 6 months like any disposable Bic lighter. (Bic's are truly airtight). So a Zippo is not what you want to leave inside your long term emergency evacuation bag --the Bics are a better choice for any standby kit. You CAN slow down evaporation about 50% by storing the ZIPPO in a ziplock freezer bag.

This is a great, useful fun retro item and a beautiful piece of Americana to own. Also check out the Street Chrome, Satin Chrome, Black Crackle, Camo, Olive Green Matte and 1941 Replica models.

At $11-12 delivered this is less than half what you would pay at a smoke shop or retail outlet. Classic ZIPPO, fire in your hand, what's not to love?

Hope this is helpful. Happy 'clicking', everybody.

reviews.title: One Star
reviews.body:
I love this lighter. First of all, I do smoke a pipe and, sometimes cigars. This Zippo works well with either. I buy stuff to actually use, so I don't care if it gets scratches and such. I carried a Zippo back in the 60's while in the Air Force and never wore one out. I did lose several though. My favorite ( black Playboy one) was carried and used daily for about 4 yrs before I lost it. I have never had to replace a wick in one. Average flint change is about 2 months with most of them (with heavy use). I fill mine about every 3-4 days to keep from burning the wicks out, but have gone around 7 days before it actually ran out.
I do not notice any odor or unpleasant taste with quality fuels. In fact a wooden match gives me a worse taste than any lighter on average. Also, after refilling, I wipe mine off with a paper towel or old cloth and give it a burn or two before putting in my pocket.

Pros: 1. Work best with Ronsonol, Zippo, or Naptha fluid. 2. Will work well with Coleman White Gas (like for Coleman Stoves), but I do notice a little odor with it. Will work with unleaded gas in a pinch, but really has a gas odor. 3. Works in wind better than anything except maybe a butane jet lighter. 4. Works at any altitude that I've been. 5. Lasts forever and has warranty. 6. Is high quality and made in U.S.A. 7. Inexpensive for good basic model like this one. 8. Can replace wicks and flints, and both are cheap to replace. 9. Will pay for itself in the place of about 4 disposable lighters.
Cons: 1. Needs to be refilled with liquid fuel, NOT BUTANE. 2. Fluid drys/evaporates in average 6 or so days. 3. Need to replace flints every few months. 4. May need to replace wick if it burns out. 5. Some fuels have more odor than others. 6. Fuel can irritate your skin if you don't wipe it down after refilling.

It really is a great size for your pocket, or for people with smaller hands, but it's still just as easy to handle as the original size. And of course it has that infamous Zippo high quality. It's easy to fill, easy to handle, and an overall excellent lighter, especially for this price.

reviews.body:
I never had a Zippo lighter. And because I heard so much about them, I decided to get one.

I chose this particular lighter with a Brushed Chrome finish because it was simple and classy. The brushed finish would help make fingerprints less prominent, and the silver is easy to find.

LIGHTER FLUID
It's recommended you use official Zippo Lighter Fluid to fuel these lighters. Adding the fluid is easy:
First, flip the lighter open
Second, pull out the lighter portion from its shell
Third, turn it upside down and lift up the cotton-looking piece (use a pen or knife)
Fourth, pour the lighter fluid in slowly, until it's just above the cotton piece (not over!)
Put the lighter portion back in, give it a minute to soak up, and you can starting lighting.

It works well. It has Zippo's signature sound when you flip open the lighter. And now I want a prettier design. Recommended.

reviews.body: This is the second Failed Zippo Lighter I've purchased because I bought lots of fuel that I needed to use up. The first one stopped working. This one burned my fingers. The mechanism for refilling is fraught with danger. You just spray the fluid in a cotton-like substance and then wipe down all the lighter fluid you get all over everywhere. I'm not kidding. You can go to zippo.com/care and confirm. But the residue of fluid is everywhere, so the flame burst out, and it took me a while to get the thing put out, because it was doused in lighter fluid. Not up to modern standards of safety. I just can't believe the good reviews and lack of law-suites (not endorsing them, but they are a part of modern american life). And I'm pretty mechanical and meticulous when it comes to instructions, so I don't think you can point to user error.

author.name: Bybenjamin bannister

reviews.title: Burned my hands!
reviews.body: I collect zippo lighters for hobby and doing flipping, lighting tricks. I saw this armor lighter and wanted it for my collection. Of course I wanted super shiny chrome for the brilliant shine and good grip when doing tricks. I can say this lighter is way different than the regular zippos. It is much heavier and the distinct clink sound when opening the cover sounds different. When I opened the cover and pushed the sides together it doesn't bend and give like the regular zippos. The walls are thicker than the regular zippos and it feels heavier. I didn't do much tricks on this one because it feels very heavy and in the past I broke a couple zippo covers. Since the cover on this one is heavier I was thinking it might fly off easier with the heavy weight. This armor series is very nice and durable and has a nice bulletproof name to stand behind it. You will be happy with this strong lighter. I bought a regular chrome zippo also. Side by side comparison you can see the difference in thickness when opening the lid to look at the wall thickness. Two very different clink sounds when opening. I use the regular one for my tricks. It's also cheaper than the armor. Just by looking at it closed they look identical until you hold it and feel the weight difference and open it up. Chrome shows fingerprints and smears a lot from the oils on your hand and will show scratches easily. Unlike the brushed steel that is slippery when gripping and doesn't have that brilliant shine that the chrome has. You could probably use the chrome zippo to signal for help out at sea or stranded hiking its so shiny. Very nice zippo!

reviews.title: Its Okay.
reviews.body:
Growing up in a family of nonsmokers, I feel like I missed out on the experience of actually holding and using a classic Zippo. They certainly always looked and sounded cool in the movies! Since the barrier to ownership was a measly 8 bucks, I decided to remedy that. The Zippo is definitely all about the sensory experience these days: they aren't practical, since the fuel will evaporate over time and you'll have to refill it all the time even if you don't use it. They basically only work to light anything when you can hold it upright, or very close to upright. That said, they have such a lovely sound - which I don't need to describe to anybody - and the coolness of snapping it closed one-handed is a real thing. The tall flame is also very nice and much hotter than a Bic or similar flame, plus you don't need to put pressure on anything to keep it burning.

I can see how, for a smoker, these could be more convenient, since the motions of using one are so effortless once you get used to it. For the rest of us, it's a great alternative to a fidget spinner complete with sound and light show. High quality, excellent flame, but impractical.
